provisions.title: Amendment to Section VI – Revised Compliance Monitoring Provision
provisions.summary: Section VI of the original March 13, 2015 Final Order is amended so that John Fanning must notify the Commission for five years (running from the date of the original Final Order's issuance) whenever he discontinues his current business or employment, or affiliates with any new business or employment involving electronic commerce, social media, or the online collection or use of consumer data linked to a specific consumer, computer, or device. Notices must include the new business address, telephone number, a description of the business or employment, and his duties and responsibilities, and must be delivered by email or overnight courier to the specified FTC address.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Preservation of All Other Provisions of the Original Final Order
provisions.summary: All portions of the Commission's original Final Order issued on March 13, 2015, other than Section VI (which is replaced by the revised compliance monitoring provision above), remain in effect without any modification.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Affirmative Express Consent Provision
provisions.summary: No later than 120 days after service of the Order, Respondent must not preinstall any covered software unless affirmative express consent is obtained from the consumer, revocation instructions are provided, and a reasonable opt-out or removal mechanism is available.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Billing Without Express, Informed Consent
provisions.summary: Respondent is prohibited from billing an Account Holder for any Charge without first obtaining Express, Informed Consent. If Respondent obtains consent for future charges, it must provide a simple mechanism to revoke that consent at any time.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Denying Account Access for Disputing Charges
provisions.summary: Respondent is permanently prohibited from denying, temporarily or permanently, a consumer's access to or use of their account — including any paid-for goods or services — for reasons that include the consumer's dispute of a Charge.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Monetary Relief
provisions.summary: Respondent must pay $245,000,000 to the Commission within 8 days of the effective date of this Order by electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Respondent relinquishes all rights to assets transferred under this Order; complaint facts are taken as true in subsequent litigation; money paid may be used for consumer redress; interest accrues on default; daily nonpayment constitutes a separate violation; and Respondent's Taxpayer ID may be used for collecting delinquent amounts.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Customer Information
provisions.summary: Respondent must provide sufficient customer information to enable the Commission to administer consumer redress, and must respond to any written Commission request for redress-related information within 14 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Acknowledgments of the Order
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 10 days, deliver copies to key personnel within 10 days, and obtain signed acknowledgments from each recipient within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Report and Notices
provisions.summary: Respondent must submit a sworn compliance report one year after issuance, provide sworn compliance notices within 14 days of certain structural or contact changes for 10 years, and notify the Commission within 14 days of any bankruptcy filing.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Respondent must create and retain specified records for 10 years (with 5-year retention), including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, research/testing records, law enforcement communications, custodial records, and all compliance-related records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC may monitor Respondent's compliance by requiring additional reports and records within 10 days of written request, communicating directly with and interviewing Respondent's personnel, and using all other lawful means including undercover investigation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Order Effective Dates and Duration
provisions.summary: This Order is effective upon publication on the FTC's website and terminates 20 years from the date of issuance, or 20 years from the most recent date a complaint alleging a violation of this Order is filed in federal court, whichever is later.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5 of the Federal Trade Commission Act

provisions.title: Ban on Sales to Children and Early Teens Without a Parent's Affirmative Express Consent
provisions.summary: Within six months of the Effective Date, Defendants are permanently enjoined from allowing accounts associated with Children or Early Teens to spend fiat currency or cryptocurrency in-game without first obtaining Affirmative Express Consent from a parent, following Clear and Conspicuous disclosure of key material terms.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Ban Against Sales of Chances via Covered Mechanism Without a Fiat Currency Direct Purchase Option
provisions.summary: Within six months of the Effective Date, Defendants are permanently enjoined from offering Covered Mechanism transactions without also providing consumers a direct fiat currency purchase option, presented at the same time and clearly indicating the cost.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from making express or implied misrepresentations about Covered Mechanisms, the likelihood of obtaining digital content, costs, or any other material fact concerning any Covered Product or Service.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Required Disclosures for Covered Mechanisms and Multi-Tiered Virtual Currency
provisions.summary: Within six months of the Effective Date, Defendants must clearly and conspicuously disclose odds and costs at points of sale for Covered Mechanisms, disclose virtual currency bundle details, and maintain an online notice on their website and game login screen with complete odds and cost information.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Monetary Judgments
provisions.summary: A civil penalty judgment of $20,000,000 is entered jointly and severally against Defendants, payable to the U.S. Treasury within 14 days of entry of the Order by electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Defendants relinquish all rights to assets transferred under the Order, facts in the Complaint may be taken as true in subsequent civil litigation, and Defendants must submit their Taxpayer Identification Numbers to the Commission.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Each Defendant must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 10 days, deliver copies of the Order to key personnel within 10 days (and to new personnel before they assume responsibilities), and obtain signed acknowledgments from all recipients within 30 days of delivery.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Each Defendant must submit a sworn compliance report one year after entry of the Order covering contact information, business details, Covered Products/Services, and compliance status; provide sworn compliance notices within 14 days of any structural or contact changes for 10 years; notify the Commission of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days; and submit all required materials to the Commission by email or overnight courier.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Each Defendant must create specified records for 10 years after entry of the Order and retain each record for 5 years, covering accounting revenues, personnel records, consumer complaints and refund requests, and all records necessary to demonstrate full compliance.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The Commission and Plaintiff are authorized to monitor Defendants' compliance by requesting additional reports, conducting depositions and discovery, communicating directly with Defendants and their personnel, and using undercover methods, all without further leave of court.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998 (COPPA), 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule (COPPA Rule), 16 C.F.R. pt. 312

provisions.title: Prohibited Business Activities — Misrepresentation of FCRA Affiliation
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from misrepresenting, or assisting others in misrepresenting, any affiliation with the annual free credit report available under the Fair Credit Reporting Act or any other federal law.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Change of Notification Address
provisions.summary: The address for all written notifications to the Commission is changed from the address in the Final Order to the FTC's Division of Enforcement address in Washington, D.C.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Record Keeping
provisions.summary: For six years from the date of entry, Defendant must create and retain specified business records including accounting, personnel, customer, complaint, marketing, and compliance records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Distribution of Supplemental Order by Defendant
provisions.summary: For three years from entry, Defendant must deliver a copy or accurate summary of the Supplemental Order to principals, officers, directors, relevant managers, and employees, and obtain signed acknowledgments of receipt within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Supplemental Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Costs and Attorney's Fees
provisions.summary: Each party shall bear its own costs and attorney's fees incurred in connection with this action.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a), and Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from misrepresenting material facts about talent casting opportunities, consumer selection for roles, and practices regarding children's personal information or any goods or services.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), and 16(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), and 56(a); Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c) and 6505(d); and the Children's Online Privacy Protection Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 312

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Settling Defendant and all persons acting with it are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting that they have detected security or performance issues on a consumer's Electronic Device, or any other material fact concerning technical support goods or services.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Software Provider Review, Termination and Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Settling Defendant must review existing and prospective Software Providers for prohibited conduct, suspend or terminate non-compliant providers, and maintain records of all reviews and actions taken.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Monetary Judgment
provisions.summary: A monetary judgment of $25,000,000 is entered against Settling Defendant, to be paid to the FTC within 14 days of entry of the Order by electronic fund transfer.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Additional Monetary Provisions
provisions.summary: Settling Defendant relinquishes all rights to transferred assets, agrees that Complaint facts may be taken as true in future proceedings, acknowledges use of its tax ID for collections, and permits the FTC to use paid funds for equitable relief including consumer redress.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Customer Information
provisions.summary: Settling Defendant must provide sufficient customer information to enable the FTC to administer consumer redress, and must supply any requested information within 14 days of a written request.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Order Acknowledgments
provisions.summary: Settling Defendant must submit a sworn acknowledgment of receipt of the Order within 7 days, deliver copies to key personnel within 7 days (and to future personnel before they assume responsibilities), and obtain signed acknowledgments from all recipients within 30 days.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: Settling Defendant must file a sworn compliance report one year after entry, submit sworn notices within 14 days of structural or contact changes for 10 years, notify the FTC of any bankruptcy filing within 14 days, and submit all required filings by email or overnight courier.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Recordkeeping
provisions.summary: Settling Defendant must create specified records for 10 years and retain each for 5 years, including accounting records, personnel records, consumer complaints, compliance documentation, and copies of all marketing materials.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: The FTC is authorized to monitor Settling Defendant's compliance through written requests for reports and documents, depositions, direct communications with employees, and undercover investigative methods; Settling Defendant must respond within 21 days of written requests.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Default Privacy Settings for Children and Teens
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently enjoined from disclosing or enabling disclosure of a Child's or Teen's Covered Information to other users, or enabling a Child or Teen to converse with other users, unless the applicable parent or Teen has provided Affirmative Express Consent through an easily-located Privacy Setting.
provisions.legal_authority: Sections 5(a)(1), 5(m)(1)(A), 13(b), 16(a)(1), and 19 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 45(a)(1), 45(m)(1)(A), 53(b), 56(a)(1), 57b, and Sections 1303(c) and 1306(d) of the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act of 1998, 15 U.S.C. §§ 6502(c), 6505(d)

provisions.title: Permanent Injunction — Negative Option Marketing
provisions.summary: Brown and Credit Bureau Center were permanently enjoined from using negative-option marketing features that automatically enroll consumers in paid subscriptions without clear and conspicuous disclosure of all material terms before obtaining billing information, in violation of ROSCA.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 5 of the Restore Online Shoppers' Confidence Act (ROSCA), 15 U.S.C. § 8404; Section 621(a)(1) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act (FCRA), 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a)(1)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations Related to Negative Options
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently prohibited from misrepresenting any material aspect of its Negative Option Feature offers, including cancellation terms, costs, free-trial claims, billing authorization, and refund or cancellation policies.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 5(m)(1)(A) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(m)(1)(A); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018, 15 U.S.C. § 45d; Section 5 of the Restore Online Shoppers' Confidence Act (ROSCA), 15 U.S.C. § 8404

provisions.title: Required Disclosures Relating to Negative Option Feature
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently prohibited from promoting any Negative Option Feature without making specific Clear and Conspicuous disclosures about costs, affirmative action required to avoid charges, recurring charge deadlines, and cancellation mechanisms; and must send written transaction confirmations to consumers.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 5(m)(1)(A) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(m)(1)(A); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018, 15 U.S.C. § 45d; Section 5 of the Restore Online Shoppers' Confidence Act (ROSCA), 15 U.S.C. § 8404

provisions.title: Obtaining Express Informed Consent for a Negative Option
provisions.summary: Defendant must obtain the consumer's express informed consent before using Billing Information for a Negative Option Feature, through a standalone affirmative checkbox or signature for written offers, or oral confirmation for telephone offers, with voice recordings retained for 3 years for telemarketing transactions.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 5(m)(1)(A) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(m)(1)(A); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018, 15 U.S.C. § 45d; Section 5 of the Restore Online Shoppers' Confidence Act (ROSCA), 15 U.S.C. § 8404

provisions.title: Simple Mechanism to Cancel Negative Option Feature
provisions.summary: Defendant must provide consumers with a simple, easy-to-find, and easy-to-use cancellation mechanism that does not require unnecessary steps or use Dark Patterns, available through the same channel (Internet, phone, or mail) through which the consumer enrolled.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 5(m)(1)(A) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(m)(1)(A); Section 13(b) of the FTC Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); Section 8023 of the Opioid Addiction Recovery Fraud Prevention Act of 2018, 15 U.S.C. § 45d; Section 5 of the Restore Online Shoppers' Confidence Act (ROSCA), 15 U.S.C. § 8404

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting to U.S. consumers any aspect of their data practices, use of engager profiles, authenticity of user profiles, number of actual users, account deletion terms, third-party awards, or participation in privacy/security programs.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b)

provisions.title: Prohibition on Misrepresentations
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting any material facts about how their file-sharing application operates, including which files will be shared, with whom, and how consumers can control sharing.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Required Disclosures and Defaults Relating to the Sharing of Downloaded Files
provisions.summary: Defendants may not distribute any file-sharing application unless it clearly discloses sharing behavior before installation, requires affirmative consumer selection of files to share, and provides easy mechanisms to disable sharing after installation.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Requirements Relating to User-Originated Files and Default Settings
provisions.summary: Defendants may not distribute any file-sharing application capable of sharing user-originated files unless sharing of such files can only be enabled after complete installation, with clear disclosures, affirmative consumer selection, and easy mechanisms to reverse sharing.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations to Consumers Regarding Covered Reports
provisions.summary: Settling Defendants are permanently enjoined from making any misrepresentations, expressly or by implication, about Covered Reports, including misrepresentations about the effect of removal mechanisms, the probability of Covered Records existing, accuracy, whether traffic tickets are criminal records, or any other facts about Covered Records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); and Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a)

provisions.title: Injunction Concerning Misrepresentations in Violation of Section 5 of the FTC Act
provisions.summary: Settling Defendants are permanently enjoined from making or assisting in any misrepresentation about what a user can achieve with a product or service, or about the status of any reviewer or endorser, including misrepresentations that a reviewer is an unbiased or ordinary user.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); and Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a)

provisions.title: Required Disclosures of Unexpected Material Connections
provisions.summary: Settling Defendants are permanently enjoined from making any representation about any reviewer or endorser of a Covered Report or related good or service without Clearly and Conspicuously disclosing, in Close Proximity to that representation, any Unexpected Material Connection between the reviewer or endorser and the Settling Defendants or affiliated entities.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); and Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a)

provisions.title: Monitoring of Endorsers
provisions.summary: Within 90 days of entry of the order, Settling Defendants must implement steps to ensure compliance with endorser disclosure requirements, including providing clear disclosure statements to each reviewer, obtaining signed acknowledgments, establishing a monitoring system for endorser representations, contacting non-compliant endorsers, and creating monitoring reports.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 13(b) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 53(b); and Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a)

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Misrepresentations to Consumers
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from misrepresenting, expressly or by implication, what users can achieve with the service, payment or cancellation terms, company policies, the likelihood a consumer has Covered Records, or any other material fact regarding Covered Records.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 56(a)(1); Telemarketing Sales Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 310; Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1681x; Restore Online Shoppers' Confidence Act, 15 U.S.C. § 8404

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Unsubstantiated Representations Regarding Covered Records
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from stating that a consumer may have, does have, or that there are possible Covered Records, unless the representation is non-misleading and Defendants have actually found a Covered Record about that consumer from a third-party source.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 56(a)(1); Telemarketing Sales Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 310; Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1681x; Restore Online Shoppers' Confidence Act, 15 U.S.C. § 8404

provisions.title: Prohibition Against Statements Regarding Traffic Tickets
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from stating, directly or by implication, that a traffic ticket or traffic citation is a criminal or arrest record.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 56(a)(1); Telemarketing Sales Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 310; Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1681x; Restore Online Shoppers' Confidence Act, 15 U.S.C. § 8404

provisions.title: Ban on Negative Options
provisions.summary: Defendants are permanently enjoined from advertising, marketing, promoting, or offering for sale any product or service with a Negative Option Feature.
provisions.legal_authority: Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a); Section 16(a)(1) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 56(a)(1); Telemarketing Sales Rule, 16 C.F.R. Part 310; Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681-1681x; Restore Online Shoppers' Confidence Act, 15 U.S.C. § 8404
